chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Ladies and gentlemen, I'd like to get started.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: My name's Eric Grimson.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I have the privilege of serving as MIT's chancellor

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: for academic advancement.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You can go look up what that means.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And like John, I'm a former head of course six.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And today, or this term with Anna and John,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I'm going to be splitting the lectures.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So I'm up today.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: OK, last time, Anna introduced the first of the compound data

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: types, tuples and lists.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Tuples and lists.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: She showed lots of ways of manipulating them,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: lots of built-in things for manipulating those structures.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the key difference between the two of them

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: was that tuples were immutable, meaning you could not

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: change them.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Lists were mutable.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: They could be changed or mutated.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And that led to both some nice power and some opportunities

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: for challenges.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And in particular, she showed you things like aliasing,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: where you could have two names pointing to the same list

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: structure.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And because of that, you could change the contents of one.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It would change the appearance of the contents of the other.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And that leads to some nice challenges.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So the side effects of mutability

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: are one of the things you're going

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to see both as a plus and a minus as we go through the course.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Today, we're going to take a different direction

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: for a little while.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We're going to talk about recursion.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It's a powerful and wonderful tool

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: for solving computational problems.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We're then going to look at another type of compound data

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: structure, a dictionary, which is also mutable.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then we're going to put the two pieces together

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and show how together they actually

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: give you a lot of power for solving some really neat

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: problems very effectively.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But I want to start with recursion.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Perhaps one of the most mysterious,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: at least according to programmers,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: concepts in computer science, one

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that leads to lots of really bad computer science jokes.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Actually, all computer science jokes are bad,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: but these are particularly bad.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So let's start with the obvious question.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: What is recursion?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: If you go to the ultimate source of knowledge, Wikipedia,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you get something that says, in essence,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: recursion is the process of repeating items

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: in a self-similar way.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Well, that's really helpful, right?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But we're going to see that idea,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: because recursion, as we're going to see in a second,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is the idea of taking a problem and reducing it

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to a smaller version of the same problem,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and using that idea to actually tackle

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: a bunch of really interesting problems.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But recursion gets used a lot of places.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So it's this idea of using or repeating

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: the idea multiple times.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So wouldn't it be great if your 3D printer printed 3D printers,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and you could just keep doing that all the way along?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Or one that's a little more common.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It's actually got a wonderful name.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It's called mise en abyme in art, sometimes referred

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to as the Drost effect.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Pictures that have inside them a picture of the picture,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: which has inside them a picture of the picture,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and you get the idea.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And of course, one of the things you

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: want to think about in recursion is not

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to have it go on infinitely.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And yes, there are even light bulb jokes about recursion.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: If you can't read it, it says, how many twists does it

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: take to screw in a light bulb?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And it says, if it's already screwed in, the answer is zero.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Otherwise, twist it once, ask me again, add one to my answer.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And that's actually a nice description of recursion.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So let's look at it more seriously.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: What is recursion?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I want to describe it both abstractly,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: or algorithmically, and semantically,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: or if you like, in terms of programming.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Abstractly, this is a great instance of something often

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: called divide and conquer, or sometimes

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: called decrease and conquer.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the idea of recursion is I want

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to take a problem I'm trying to solve and say,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: how could I reduce it to a simpler

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: version of the same problem plus some things I know how to do?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then that simpler version, I'm going to reduce it again

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and keep doing that until I get down to a simple case

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that I can solve directly.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That is how we're going to think about designing solutions

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to problems.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Semantically, this is typically going

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to lead to the case where a program, a definition,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: a function, will refer to itself in its body.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It will call itself inside its body.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Now, if you remember your high school geometry teacher,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: she probably would wrap your knuckles,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: which you're not allowed to do, because in things like geometry,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you can't define something in terms of itself.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That's not allowed.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: In recursion, this is OK.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Our definition of a procedure can, in its body,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: call itself.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So long as I have what I call a base case,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: a way of stopping that unwinding of the problems,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: when I get to something I can solve directly.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And so what we're going to do is avoid infinite recursion

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: by ensuring that we have at least one or more base

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: cases that are easy to solve.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then the basic idea is I just

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: want to solve the same problem on some simpler input

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: with the idea of using that solution to solve

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: the larger problem.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: OK, let's look at an example.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And to set the stage, I'm going to go back to something

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you've been doing, iterative algorithms.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: For loops, while loops, they naturally

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: lead to what we would call iterative algorithms.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And these algorithms can be described

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: as being captured by a set of state variables, meaning

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: one or more variables that tell us exactly

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: the state of the computation.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It's a lot of words.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Let's look at an example.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I know it's trivial, but bear with me.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Suppose I want to do integer multiplication, multiply

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: two integers together.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And all I have available to me is addition.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So a times b is the same as adding a to itself b times.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: If I'm thinking about this iteratively,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I could capture this computation

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: with two state variables.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: One would just call the iteration number.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And it would be something, for example, that starts at b.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And each time through the loop reduces by one.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And it will keep doing that until I've counted down b

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: times and it get down to zero.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And at the same time, I would have

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: some value of the computation.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I might call it result, which starts at zero, first time

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: through adds in a, next time through adds in day.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And it just keeps track of how many things have I added up

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: until I get done.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And yeah, I know you could just do mult.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But this is trying to get this idea of how would I

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: do this iteratively.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So I might start off with i saying there are b things still

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to add and result is one.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The first time through the loop, I add in a, reduce i by one.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Next time through the loop, I add in another a,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: reduce i by one.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And you get the idea.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I just walk down it until eventually I

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: got to the end of this computation.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we could write code for this.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And actually, it should be pretty straightforward.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: There it is.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Going to call it multiter.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Takes in two arguments, a and b.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And I'm going to capture exactly that process.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So notice what I do.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I set up result internally as just a little variable

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I'm going to use to accumulate things.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then there's the iteration.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: As long as b is greater than zero, what do I do?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Add a to result, store it away.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Reduce b by one.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And I'll keep doing that until b gets down to being equal to zero,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: in which case I just return the result.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Simple solution.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Now, let's think about this a different way.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: a times b is just adding a to itself b times.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And that's the same as a plus adding a to itself b minus 1

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: times.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That sounds like leisure domain.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That sounds like just playing with words.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But it's really important, because what is this?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That's just a times b minus 1, by the definition

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: at the top point.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And I know you're totally impressed.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But this is actually really cool.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Because what have I done?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I've taken one problem, this one up here,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and I've reduced it to a simpler version of the same problem,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: plus some things I know how to do.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And how would I solve this?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Same trick.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That's a times b minus 2.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I would just unwrap it one more time.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And I would just keep doing that until I get down to something

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I can solve directly.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: A base case.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And that's easy.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: When b is equal to 1, the answer is just a.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Or I could do when b is equal to 0, the answer is just 0.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And there's code to capture that.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Different form.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Wonderful compact description.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: What does it say?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It says, if I'm at the base case, if b is equal to 1,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: the answer is just a.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Otherwise, I'm going to solve the same problem

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: with a smaller version, and add it to a,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and return that result.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That's nice, crisp characterization of a problem.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Recursive definition that reduces a problem

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to a simpler version of the same problem.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: OK.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Let's look at another example.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Classic problem in recursion is to compute factorial.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: N factorial, or n bang if you like, n exclamation point

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is n times n minus 1 all the way down to 1.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So it's the product of all the integers from 1 up to n,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: assuming n is a positive integer.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we could ask the same question.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: If I wanted to solve this recursively,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: what would the base case be?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Well, when n is equal to 1, it's just 1.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: In the recursive case, well, n times n minus 1

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: all the way down to 1, that's the same as n times n minus 1

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: factorial.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So I can easily write out the base case.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And I've got a nice recursive solution to this problem.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: OK.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: If you're like me and this is the first time you see it,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: it feels like I've taken your head and twisted it

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: about 180 degrees.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I'm going to take it another 180 degrees.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Because you might be saying, well, wait a minute.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: How do you know what really stops?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: How do you know what really terminates the computation?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So let's look at it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: There is my definition for fact, short for factorial.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Right?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Fact of n is if n is equal to 1, return 1.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Otherwise, return n times fact of n minus 1.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And let's use the tools that Anna talked about in terms

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: of an environment and a scope and think

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: about what happens here.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So when I read that in or I evaluate that in Python,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: it creates a definition that binds the name fact

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to some code, just all of that stuff over here plus the name

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: for the formal parameter.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It hasn't done anything with it yet.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then I'm going to evaluate print of fact of 4.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Print needs a value, so it has to get the value of 4.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Print needs a value, so it has to get the value of fact of 4.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And we know what that does.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It looks up fact.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: There it is, its procedure definition.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So it creates a new frame, a new environment.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It calls that procedure.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And inside that frame, the formal parameter for fact

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is bound to the value passed in.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So n is bound to 4.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That frame is scoped by this global frame,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: meaning it's going to inherit things in the global frame.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And what does it do?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Inside of this frame, evaluate the body of fact.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So it says, is n equal to 1?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Nope.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It's 4.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So in that case, go to the else statement and it says,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: oh, return n times fact of n.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And n is 4.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Fact of n minus 1 says, I need to return 4 times fact of 3.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: 4 is easy.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Multiplication is easy.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Fact of 3, ah, yes.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I look up fact.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Now, I'm in this frame.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I don't see fact there, but I go up to that frame.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: There's the definition for fact.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And we're going to do the rest of this a little more quickly.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: What does that do?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It creates a new frame called by fact.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the argument passed in for n is n minus 1.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That value right there of 3.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So 3 is now bound to n.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Same game.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Evaluate the body.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Is n equal to 1?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: No.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So in that case, I'm going to go to the return statement.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It says, return 3 times fact of 2.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And notice it's only looking at this value of n,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: because that's the frame in which I'm in.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It never sees that value of n.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: OK, aren't you glad I didn't do fact of 400?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We only got two more to go.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But you get the idea.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Same thing.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I need to get fact of 2.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I'm just going to call fact again with n bound to 2.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Relative to that, evaluates the body.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: n is not yet equal to 1.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That says I'm going to the else clause

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and return 2 times fact of 1.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I call fact again, now with n bound to 1.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And fortunately, now that clause is true.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And it says, return 1.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Oops, sorry, before I do it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So there's the base case.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And it may seem apparent to you, but this is important.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I'm unwinding this till I get to something

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that can stop the computation.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Now I'm simply going to gather the computation up,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: because it says, return 1.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Who asked for it?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Well, that called a fact of 1.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So that reduces to return 2 times 1.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And who called for that?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Fact of 2.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That reduces to return of 3 times 2,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: which reduces to 4 times 6, which

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: reduces to printing out 24.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So it unwinds it down to a base case, and it stops.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Couple of observations.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Notice how each recursive call creates its own frame.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And as a consequence, there's no confusion about which value

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: of n I'm using.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Also notice in the other frames, n was not changed.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We did not mutate it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we're literally creating a local scope

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: for that recursive call, which is exactly what we want.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Also notice how there was a sense of flow of control.

chunks.title: Lecture

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: If you haven't seen this, here's the idea

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: of mathematical induction.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: If I want to prove a statement, and we refer to it

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: as being indexed on the integers, in other words,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: it's some mathematical statement that runs over integers.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: If I want to prove it's true for all values of those integers,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: mathematically, I do it by simply proving

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: it's true for the smallest value of n.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Typically, n is equal to 0 or 1.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then I do an interesting thing.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I say, I need to prove that if it's

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: true for an arbitrary value of n,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I'm just going to prove that it's also then true for n plus 1.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And if I can do those two things,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I can then conclude for an infinite number of values of n,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: it's always true.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I'm going to relate it back to programming in a second,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: but let me show you a simple example of this,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: one that you may have seen.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: If I add the integers from 0 up to n, or even from 1 up to n,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I claim that's the same as n times n plus 1 over 2.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So 1, 2, 3, that's 6, right?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And that's exactly right, 3 times 4,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: which is divided by 2, which gives me out 6.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: How would I prove this?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Well, by induction, I need to do the simple case.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Is van A is equal to 0?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Well, then this side is just 0, and that's 0 times 1,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: which is 0 divided by true.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So 0 equals 0, it's true.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Now the inductive step.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I'm going to assume it's true for some k.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I should have picked n, but for some k.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then what I need to show is it's true for k plus 1.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Well, there's the left-hand side,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and I want to show that this is equal to that.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And I'm going to do it by using exactly this recursive idea,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: because what do I know?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I know that this sum in here, I'm assuming is true.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And so that says that the left-hand side,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: the first portion of it, is just k times k plus 1 over 2.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That's the definition of the thing I'm assuming is true.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: To that, I'm going to add k plus 1.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Well, you can do the algebra, right?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That's k plus 1 all times k over 2 plus 1,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: which is k plus 2 over 2.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Oh, cool.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It's exactly that.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Having done that, I can now conclude

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: this is true for all values of n.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: What does it have to do with programming?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: That's exactly what we're doing when

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: we think about recursive code.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We're saying show that it's true for the base case.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then what I'm essentially assuming

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is that if it works for values smaller than b,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: then does the code return the right answer for b?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the answer is absolutely it does.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And I'm using induction to deduce that, in fact, my code

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: does the right thing.
